text: I slowly reached for my short sword—only for the scabbard to brush against my belt with a faint metallic clang.
The drunkard snapped his head around, bloodshot eyes glaring at me. “What do you think you’re doing?!”
His rage ignited in an instant; his fist slammed down onto the table, sending liquor splashing everywhere.
Instinctively, I took a step back. My hand hadn’t even closed around the hilt yet, but the air was already thick with tension.
Just as he took another step forward, a sharp sound sliced through the air—not wind, but the ring of a blade.
Alicia was already on her feet. Her cloak swept past the fire, and a flash of silver streaked through the room.
No one saw what she did—only that, in the next instant, the drunkard was pinned to the floor, his face buried in his own spilled drink.
“Enough.” Her voice was calm, like the sound of ice beginning to melt.
I stared at her, stunned. In that moment, I realized—I’d never needed to draw my sword at all.
She sheathed her blade, and the firelight danced across the cracked pattern on its edge.
